questions.text: A 22-year-old man develops agitation and restlessness one hour after undergoing an uncomplicated laparoscopic appendectomy. He also has tremors, diffuse sweating, headache, and nausea with dry heaves. Intraoperatively, there was approximately 100 mL of blood loss, his urine output was 100 mL, and 1 L of lactated Ringer solution was administered. His pain has been controlled with intravenous morphine. He was admitted to the hospital 3 days ago and has not eaten in 18 hours. He has no history of serious illness. He has experimented with intravenous illicit drugs. He drinks 3 beers and 2 glasses of whiskey daily during the week and more on the weekends with his college fraternity. He appears anxious. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 142/90 mm Hg. He is oriented to person, but not to time or place, and keeps asking if his father, who is not present, can leave the room. Mucous membranes are moist and the skin is warm. Cardiac examination shows tachycardia and regular rhythm. The lungs are clear to auscultation. His abdomen has three port sites with clean and dry bandages. His hands tremble when his arms are extended with fingers spread apart. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous propranolol is used in combination with antithyroid drugs to treat thyroid storm, which can occur after a stressful event (e.g., infection, surgery) in patients with hyperthyroidism and manifest with altered mental status and signs of sympathetic overstimulation. However, the severity of tachycardia is far greater in thyroid storm (heart rate usually exceeds 140/minute) and severe hyperpyrexia (> 104°F) is also typically present. The lack of a history of hyperthyroidism also makes a thyroid storm unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Alcohol activates GABA (inhibitory) receptors and chronic alcohol use downregulates GABA receptors. The abrupt cessation of a GABAergic agent (e.g., alcohol) in a patient with downregulated GABA receptors causes neuronal hyperexcitability, which is responsible for the manifestations of alcohol withdrawal, including alcohol withdrawal delirium. This condition may be lethal and must be treated urgently. The first-line therapy for alcohol withdrawal delirium is an intravenous benzodiazepine (e.g., lorazepam). Benzodiazepines are GABAergic agents and counteract neuronal hyperexcitability.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous naloxone is the first-line treatment for opioid overdose. This patient has received intravenous morphine, an opiate analgesic, for pain control. However, morphine results in decreased responsiveness, respiratory depression, and miosis. This patient has a normal respiratory rate, is alert and oriented, and does not have any pupillary abnormalities, making an opioid overdose unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous dexamethasone may be used to treat an adrenal crisis, which can occur following periods of acute stress (e.g., surgery) in patients with adrenal insufficiency and manifest with nausea and an altered mental status. However, patients with an adrenal crisis would have hypotension. The lack of a history of adrenal insufficiency also makes an adrenal crisis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

5% dextrose in half normal saline can be administered to treat severe hypernatremia, which can occur in the postoperative period as a result of dehydration and cause delirium. This patient, however, has no features suggestive of dehydration (e.g., dry mucous membranes, hypotension).

F) INCORRECT:

Dantrolene is used as first-line therapy for malignant hyperthermia, which occurs in the immediate postoperative period (as a result of the administration of medications for general anesthesia) and can manifest with diaphoresis and tachycardia. However, it usually also manifests with severe hyperthermia and muscle rigidity, neither of which are seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has an excessive drinking pattern that was disrupted for the past 3 days because of admission to the hospital. He now has sympathetic overstimulation (anxiety, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, and tremors), altered mental status, and visual hallucinations that are characteristic of alcohol withdrawal delirium, which typically occurs 72–96 hours after abrupt cessation of alcohol.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after he was found in a stuporous state with a small cut on his forehead on a cold night in front of his apartment. Noncontrast head CT is normal, and he is monitored in the emergency department. Twelve hours later, he yells for help because he hears the wallpaper threatening his family. The patient started drinking regularly 10 years ago and consumed a pint of vodka prior to admission. He occasionally smokes marijuana and uses cocaine. His vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, the patient is alert and oriented. He appears markedly distressed and is diaphoretic. A fine digital tremor on his right hand is noted. The remainder of the neurological examination shows no abnormalities. Urine toxicologic screening is pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Alcohol withdrawal occurs in stages with unique clinical manifestations. Alcohol hallucinosis occurs 12–48 hours after the last alcoholic beverage and usually presents with visual (most common), auditory, or tactile hallucinations. An intact sensorium (i.e., alert and oriented) and the absence of autonomic instability (e.g., hypertension, tachycardia, hyperthermia) help distinguish this diagnosis from delirium tremens. Alcohol hallucinosis usually resolves within 24–48 hours of onset and withdrawal symptoms can be managed with benzodiazepines.

B) INCORRECT:

Phencyclidine (PCP) intoxication can cause hallucinations. However, phencyclidine intoxication classically also causes aggressiveness, vital sign abnormalities due to autonomic instability (e.g., tachycardia, hypertension), and nystagmus, which are not seen here. Furthermore, PCP intoxication usually lasts 1–4 hours. It is therefore unlikely that this patient is still intoxicated at least 12 hours after hospitalization.

C) INCORRECT:

Cocaine intoxication can cause anxiety, diaphoresis, tremors, and hallucinations. However, physical examination typically shows vital sign abnormalities (e.g., tachycardia, hypertension) and pupillary dilation. Furthermore, since this patient has been in the hospital for over 12 hours, continued intoxication is unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's alcohol use places him at risk for thiamine deficiency and Wernicke encephalopathy. However, he is not confused and lacks ophthalmic or ataxic findings on neurological examination, making this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Delirium tremens (DT) can cause hallucinations. However, DT usually occurs between 48–96 hours after the last alcoholic beverage and patients will have vital sign abnormalities (e.g., tachycardia, hypertension) with a disrupted sensorium (e.g., lack of orientation, confusion).

F) INCORRECT:

Brief psychotic disorder or other psychotic disorders can cause hallucinations. However, this diagnosis can only be made in the absence of any substance use, and this patient consumed alcohol very recently. Furthermore, patients with brief psychotic disorder will have a normal physical exam, which is not consistent with this patient's diaphoresis and tremor.
questions.hint: The vital signs are normal and, despite the hallucinations (hearing the wallpaper speak), the patient's sensorium is intact.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for treatment of traumatic injuries. His vital signs are normal, but he is too sedated to provide a history of recent events. He is subsequently hospitalized and becomes intermittently agitated and tremulous. Vital signs include a heart rate of 116 to 128 beats per minute, a systolic blood pressure of 168 to 212 mm Hg, a diastolic blood pressure of 92 to 108 mm Hg, and a temperature of 37.6°C to 39.2°C.
On the second day of hospitalization, the patient experiences a tonic-clonic seizure that is witnessed by medical personnel. Laboratory testing reveals the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
368
0–35


Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
174
0–35


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
206
30–120


Platelet count (per mm3)
78,000
150,000–350,000


Prothrombin time (sec)

Which one of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Haloperidol, an antipsychotic medication, would not be indicated for this patient. Although psychotic symptoms can occur during alcohol withdrawal, antipsychotics do not treat the underlying alcohol withdrawal. In addition, they can lower the seizure threshold and prolong the QT interval. Antipsychotics are therefore typically used only after the withdrawal period if psychotic symptoms persist, but they are generally avoided in this situation.

B) INCORRECT:

Chlordiazepoxide, clonazepam, and alprazolam undergo both oxidative metabolism and glucuronidation, increasing a patient’s risks for sedation and respiratory depression in the presence of compromised hepatic function.

C) CORRECT:

The signs and symptoms of alcohol-withdrawal syndrome (which include tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, tremor, nausea, anxiety, and headache) typically arise within 24 to 48 hours after alcohol cessation and peak within 72 hours. Seizures, if they occur, will typically develop within 48 hours of last alcohol use.

Benzodiazepines remain a first-line treatment for alcohol-withdrawal syndrome and related seizure prophylaxis. To minimize the risks of treatment, hepatic function should be evaluated before benzodiazepines are initiated. Hepatic oxidation is diminished in individuals with liver disease, resulting in drug accumulation and the potential for excessive sedation and respiratory depression. Although most benzodiazepines are metabolized by hepatic oxidation and then glucuronidation, lorazepam and oxazepam undergo only glucuronidation, which is minimally affected by liver disease. Of these, only lorazepam is available intravenously.

Diazepam, while not an option listed here, is preferred by some experts when withdrawal symptoms are severe. It has a quicker onset and peak effect than lorazepam, which allows closer adjustment of the dose with less risk of prescribing a dose that is too high. Diazepam’s longer half-life may also allow a dosage schedule that is more gradually tapered. Nonetheless, many clinicians still prefer lorazepam over diazepam in patients with liver disease, such as the one described in the vignette, as diazepam is hepatically cleared like the other benzodiazepines listed.

Key learning point: The two benzodiazepines that are most appropriate for treating alcohol withdrawal in patients with hepatic dysfunction are lorazepam and oxazepam.

D) INCORRECT:

Chlordiazepoxide, clonazepam, and alprazolam undergo both oxidative metabolism and glucuronidation, increasing a patient’s risks for sedation and respiratory depression in the presence of compromised hepatic function.

E) INCORRECT:

Chlordiazepoxide, clonazepam, and alprazolam undergo both oxidative metabolism and glucuronidation, increasing a patient’s risks for sedation and respiratory depression in the presence of compromised hepatic function.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after becoming agitated in public near his home. He is disoriented to time and place. He remains agitated, is experiencing visual hallucinations, and reports bugs crawling on his skin where there are none. His temperature is 38.0°C, his heart rate is 122 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 167/101 mm Hg.
On physical examination, he is tremulous and diaphoretic. Blood and urine drug testing is negative.
This patient’s symptoms are most characteristic of withdrawal from use of which one of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Withdrawal symptoms after heavy use of cocaine or amphetamine include depression, fatigue, dysphoria, and anxiety.

B) INCORRECT:

Lysergic acid diethylamide does not produce physical withdrawal syndromes.

C) INCORRECT:

Withdrawal symptoms after heavy use of cocaine or amphetamine include depression, fatigue, dysphoria, and anxiety.

D) INCORRECT:

Marijuana (cannabis) withdrawal does produce symptoms such as irritability, anxiety, and sleeplessness, but it does not manifest with agitation, disorientation, hallucinations, tachycardia, hypertension, or fever.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has developed delirium tremens, which usually begins 48 hours or more after the last drink of alcohol. Findings in delirium tremens include agitation, diaphoresis, hallucinations, disorientation, inattentiveness, tachycardia, fever, and hypertension.

The earliest symptoms of alcohol withdrawal (e.g., tremulousness or anxiety) can begin within hours after the last drink. Alcohol withdrawal seizures and alcoholic hallucinosis typically occur on the first or second day.

Key learning point: Relatively abrupt onset of agitation, disorientation, hallucinations, tachycardia, hypertension, and fever are consistent with withdrawal from heavy use of alcohol.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a witnessed tonic-clonic seizure. There was no trauma during the seizure. The patient’s medical history includes hypertension, coronary artery disease, and type 2 diabetes. His current medications are hydrochlorothiazide, atenolol, metformin, and aspirin. According to his family, he smokes a pack of cigarettes and consumes 6 to 8 beers daily but does not use recreational drugs. His last alcohol consumption occurred approximately 36 hours before presentation.
His blood pressure is 160/110 mm Hg, his heart rate is 98 beats per minute and regular, and his respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute. He is afebrile but confused and diaphoretic.
A complete blood count shows mild macrocytic anemia and thrombocytopenia. A biochemical profile shows a normal glucose level, mild hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, normal kidney function, and an elevated aspartate aminotransferase level.
Chest radiography is unremarkable. Noncontrast CT of the brain shows mild volume loss. Blood and urine drug test results are negative. An electrocardiogram is notable for sinus tachycardia and motion artifact.
Thiamine, multivitamins, folate, and electrolyte repletion are administered. Three hours later, the patient becomes increasingly agitated and confused, with incoherent speech, diaphoresis, and combative behavior that persist even after the cumulative administration of 40 mg of intravenous lorazepam. Physical restraints to prevent him from disrupting his intravenous access only contribute to his agitation.
What is the most appropriate initial management option in this patient?

choices.text: Start a continuous infusion of phenytoin
Transfer to the intensive care unit, and initiate sedation
Start a continuous infusion of midazolam
Obtain repeat CT of the brain

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phenytoin infusion is not recommended for alcohol withdrawal seizures.

B) CORRECT:

Delirium from alcohol withdrawal is a clinical diagnosis characterized by hyperarousal, confusion, hallucinations, hypertension, tachycardia, fever, diaphoresis, and agitated behavior in a patient who has undergone an abrupt reduction in or cessation of alcohol consumption.

Treatment of severe withdrawal should prompt transfer or direct admission to an intensive care unit that can provide continuous oxygen and telemetry, monitor sedation, and provide airway protection. If total requirements of benzodiazepines are very high, the patient may require a drip or be considered refractory to benzodiazepine. Adjunctive therapies may include propofol, carbamazepine, and gabapentin to reduce benzodiazepine requirements. Consultation with critical care and poison control teams can aid in management.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management of acute severe alcohol withdrawal that is refractory to large doses of benzodiazepines (40 mg of lorazepam) and associated with seizures is admission to the intensive care unit for sedation and possible intubation for airway protection.

C) INCORRECT:

Electroencephalography and repeat CT are not indicated in this patient, given that the initial workup does not suggest a primary or secondary seizure disorder (stroke, traumatic brain injury, meningitis or encephalitis, or anoxia) or metabolic derangement (hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, or hypocalcemia).

D) INCORRECT:

Midazolam infusion may be used to induce anesthesia but does not prevent progression of refractory delirium.

E) INCORRECT:

Electroencephalography and repeat CT are not indicated in this patient, given that the initial workup does not suggest a primary or secondary seizure disorder (stroke, traumatic brain injury, meningitis or encephalitis, or anoxia) or metabolic derangement (hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, or hypocalcemia).

questions.text: You are caring for a 55-year-old man who is two days post–total knee replacement. He develops increasing anxiety, agitation, hand tremor, and nausea. He reports seeing a bear in his room. His pain has been managed with intravenous morphine. He has a history of advanced liver disease and drinks 7 cans of beer daily. On examination, he is diaphoretic. His temperature is 37.6°C, pulse is 118/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 146/92 mm Hg. Which one of the following drugs is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cyproheptadine is an antihistamine used in the management of serotonin syndrome. Serotonin syndrome can manifest with tremor, diaphoresis, nausea, agitation, anxiety, hypertension, and tachycardia, as seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks other features typical of this condition, such as fever, hyperreflexia, and myoclonus. Moreover, he has no history of ingestion of serotonergic drugs (e.g., antidepressants) that could cause serotonin syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Dantrolene is a muscle relaxant that inhibits Ca2+ release within myocytes. It is used as a first-line therapy for malignant hyperthermia and can also be administered in cases of suspected neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS). Although malignant hyperthermia can also cause tachycardia, it usually manifests with severe hyperthermia and muscle rigidity, neither of which are seen in this patient. NMS is also characterized by muscle rigidity and hyperthermia and usually occurs after initiation of antipsychotic therapy; this patient has no history of antipsychotic use.

C) CORRECT:

Benzodiazepines are the first-line therapy for alcohol withdrawal syndrome. Long-acting benzodiazepines with active metabolites (e.g., diazepam or chlordiazepoxide) are preferred because they result in a smoother withdrawal course. However, in a patient with advanced liver disease or acute alcoholic hepatitis, short- and intermediate-acting benzodiazepines with minimal first-pass metabolism and no active metabolites, such as lorazepam and oxazepam, should be used. Delirium tremens has a 5% mortality rate and must be treated urgently.

Key learning point: In alcohol withdrawal with liver disease, short-acting benzodiazepines with minimal hepatic metabolism—such as lorazepam or oxazepam—are preferred to reduce toxicity risk.

D) INCORRECT:

Antipsychotics, such as haloperidol, should not be used routinely in the treatment of alcohol withdrawal syndrome because they increase the risk for withdrawal seizures by lowering the seizure threshold. Moreover, these drugs may interfere with heat dissipation. Treatment with antipsychotics may be considered in case of a concomitant decompensated thought disorder (e.g., schizophrenia) after withdrawal symptoms have been successfully treated.

E) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is the first-line treatment for opioid overdose. This patient has received intravenous morphine, an opiate analgesic, for pain control. Morphine causes decreased responsiveness, respiratory depression, and miosis. This patient has a normal respiratory rate, is alert and oriented, and does not have any pupillary abnormalities, making an opioid overdose unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient has an excessive drinking pattern that was disrupted because of surgery. He now presents with symptoms of sympathetic overstimulation (e.g., agitation, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, and tremors) and visual hallucinations, which are characteristic of alcohol withdrawal delirium. This condition typically occurs 72–96 hours after cessation of drinking.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department 30 minutes after a witnessed generalized tonic-clonic seizure at home. His wife reports he stopped drinking alcohol 36 hours ago after consuming a fifth of vodka daily for months. The seizure lasted 90 seconds and resolved spontaneously. He is now alert and oriented with mild tremor and diaphoresis. Vital signs are BP, 152/88; P, 118; R, 20; T, 37.4°C (99.3°F); oxygen saturation, 99% on room air. Point-of-care glucose is 110 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform lumbar puncture to exclude CNS infection
Start phenytoin loading dose and obtain EEG monitoring
Obtain emergency head CT followed by neurology consultation
Administer lorazepam and monitor for seizure recurrence
Administer thiamine and discharge home with close follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is not indicated. This patient's presentation is consistent with alcohol withdrawal seizures occurring within the typical timeframe of 8–48 hours after alcohol cessation, and there are no clinical signs suggesting a CNS infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Phenytoin and other traditional anticonvulsants are not first-line for alcohol withdrawal seizures and are less effective than other agents in preventing recurrent withdrawal seizures.

C) INCORRECT:

Head CT may be considered in the evaluation of new-onset seizures, but in this clinical context of alcohol withdrawal seizures occurring 36 hours after cessation, medical management to prevent further seizures takes priority.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Lorazepam administration followed by monitoring for seizure recurrence is the most appropriate next step. Benzodiazepines are preferred over other anticonvulsants for alcohol withdrawal seizures, and patients require continued monitoring every 1–2 hours for 6–24 hours after seizure occurrence.

E) INCORRECT:

While thiamine supplementation is important in alcohol withdrawal management, discharging this patient is inappropriate. Patients with alcohol withdrawal seizures require immediate medical management and continued monitoring every 1–2 hours for 6–24 hours, as seizures can recur.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a 15-year history of daily alcohol consumption presents 24 hours after his last drink. He reports anxiety, nausea, and difficulty sleeping. On examination, he has coarse tremors of both hands, diaphoresis, and appears agitated. Vital signs are BP, 158/96; P, 118; R, 22; T, 38.1°C (100.6°F). He is oriented to person and place but not time and reports intermittent auditory hallucinations. What is the most appropriate pharmacological approach?

choices.text: Lorazepam 2 mg IV followed by fixed-schedule tapering
Diazepam 10 mg IV with symptom-triggered dosing
Gabapentin 300 mg orally three times daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phenobarbital is not first-line therapy for alcohol withdrawal and is typically reserved for refractory symptoms or as adjunctive therapy when first-line therapy is insufficient. Loading doses of phenobarbital carry significant risks of respiratory depression and oversedation, making another drug the safer first-line choice.

B) INCORRECT:

Antipsychotics should never be used as monotherapy for alcohol withdrawal because they lower the seizure threshold and do not address the underlying GABA dysfunction. While haloperidol may be considered as adjunctive therapy for severe psychotic symptoms, another drug remains the first-line treatment.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has severe alcohol withdrawal manifesting with altered mental status, hyperthermia, tachycardia, hypertension, and hallucinations. The patient's disorientation and hallucinations suggest a high risk for progression to delirium tremens. A fixed-schedule regimen with lorazepam provides consistent symptom control and is preferred for patients with severe withdrawal or high-risk features to prevent complications.

D) INCORRECT:

While diazepam is an appropriate benzodiazepine choice, symptom-triggered dosing is generally preferred for patients with moderate withdrawal without high-risk features. This patient's altered mental status and hallucinations suggest a higher severity that requires more structured dosing.

E) INCORRECT:

Gabapentin is considered second-line therapy for alcohol withdrawal and is typically reserved for patients with contraindications to benzodiazepines or as adjunctive therapy. Moderate to severe withdrawal symptoms require first-line benzodiazepine therapy for adequate symptom control and seizure prevention.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man was admitted to the hospital three days ago for community-acquired pneumonia. The nurse calls because the patient is now acutely agitated and confused. His medical history is significant for hypertension. He is a poor historian regarding his social habits. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 128/min, blood pressure is 165/95 mm Hg, and respirations are 24/min. On examination, he is diaphoretic, has a coarse tremor of his outstretched hands, and is disoriented to time and place. He is picking at his bedsheets and reports seeing insects on the walls. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for alcohol withdrawal delirium, also known as delirium tremens (DTs), a medical emergency. The timeline of onset three days after hospital admission is typical, as DTs usually occur 72–96 hours after the last drink. The syndrome results from abrupt cessation of alcohol in a dependent individual, leading to CNS hyperexcitability from decreased γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA)ergic inhibition and increased glutamatergic activity. Key features include autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever, diaphoresis), delirium (agitation, confusion, disorientation), and vivid visual or tactile hallucinations (e.g., seeing insects). The coarse tremor is also a characteristic finding. Management involves supportive care and benzodiazepines.

B) INCORRECT:

This is a plausible consideration, as this patient has pneumonia and a fever, which are risk factors for sepsis. Sepsis can cause altered mental status, including confusion and agitation. However, the prominent coarse tremor and specific, vivid visual and tactile hallucinations (e.g., seeing insects, picking at bedsheets) are much more characteristic of an alternative diagnosis than of sepsis-induced encephalopathy alone.

C) INCORRECT:

While opioid withdrawal can occur in a hospitalized patient, its symptoms are distinctly different. Opioid withdrawal typically manifests as a severe flu-like illness with myalgias, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, and piloerection. It does not typically cause the severe delirium, hallucinations, or profound autonomic instability (e.g., marked hypertension and tachycardia) seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Intoxication with stimulants such as cocaine or amphetamines can cause agitation, psychosis, hallucinations, and autonomic hyperactivity. However, this is an intoxication syndrome. It is highly unlikely for a patient to become acutely intoxicated with stimulants three days into a hospital admission.
questions.hint: The combination of autonomic hyperactivity, disorientation, and vivid hallucinations is characteristic of this patient's condition.

questions.text: Two days after undergoing uncomplicated total knee replacement, a 55-year-old man develops increasing anxiety, agitation, hand tremor, and nausea. He told the nurse he saw a bear in his room. His pain has been controlled with intravenous morphine. He has a history of advanced liver disease. He drinks 7 cans of beer daily. He is diaphoretic. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 146/92 mm Hg. Administration of which of the following drugs is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is the first-line treatment for opioid overdose. This patient has received intravenous morphine, an opiate analgesic, for pain control. Morphine causes decreased responsiveness, respiratory depression, and miosis. This patient has a normal respiratory rate, is alert and oriented, and does not have any pupillary abnormalities, making an opioid overdose unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Chlordiazepoxide is a long-acting benzodiazepine and a first-line treatment for alcohol withdrawal syndrome. However, chlordiazepoxide undergoes hepatic metabolism and should be avoided in patients with severe liver disease, such as this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Cyproheptadine is an antihistamine used in the management of serotonin syndrome. Serotonin syndrome can manifest with tremor, diaphoresis, nausea, agitation, anxiety, hypertension, and tachycardia, as seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks other features typical of this condition, such as fever, hyperreflexia, and myoclonus. Moreover, he has no history of ingestion of serotonergic drugs (e.g., antidepressants) that could cause serotonin syndrome.

D) CORRECT:

Benzodiazepines are the first-line therapy for alcohol withdrawal syndrome. Long-acting benzodiazepines with active metabolites (e.g., diazepam or chlordiazepoxide) are preferred because they result in a smoother withdrawal course. However, in a patient with advanced liver disease or acute alcoholic hepatitis, short- and intermediate-acting benzodiazepines with minimal first-pass metabolism and no active metabolites, such as lorazepam and oxazepam, should be used. Delirium tremens has a 5% mortality rate and must be treated urgently.

Alcohol is a CNS depressant. Chronic alcohol use results in an adaptive response to persistent inhibitory tone. This response includes decreased sensitivity to GABA (an inhibitory neurotransmitter) and upregulation of the NMDA receptor (which is activated by glutamate, an excitatory neurotransmitter). Cessation of alcohol use results in decreased inhibitory tone, which results in the manifestations of alcohol withdrawal (e.g., tachycardia, hypertension, tremors, anxiety, hallucinations, seizures).

E) INCORRECT:

Dantrolene is a muscle relaxant that inhibits Ca2+ release within myocytes. It is used as a first-line therapy for malignant hyperthermia and can also be administered in cases of suspected neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS). Although malignant hyperthermia can also cause tachycardia, it usually manifests with severe hyperthermia and muscle rigidity, neither of which are seen in this patient. NMS is also characterized by muscle rigidity and hyperthermia and usually occurs after initiation of antipsychotic therapy; this patient has no history of antipsychotic use.

F) INCORRECT:

Moreover, these drugs may interfere with heat dissipation. Treatment with antipsychotics may be considered in case of a concomitant decompensated thought disorder (e.g., schizophrenia) after withdrawal symptoms have been successfully treated.

questions.text: Two days after undergoing uncomplicated total knee replacement, a 55-year-old man develops increasing anxiety, agitation, hand tremor, and nausea. He told the nurse he saw a bear in his room. His pain has been controlled with intravenous morphine. He has a history of advanced liver disease. He drinks 7 cans of beer daily. He is diaphoretic. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 146/92 mm Hg. Administration of which of the following drugs is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is the first-line treatment for opioid overdose. This patient has received intravenous morphine, an opiate analgesic, for pain control. Morphine causes decreased responsiveness, respiratory depression, and miosis. This patient has a normal respiratory rate, is alert and oriented, and does not have any pupillary abnormalities, making an opioid overdose unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Cyproheptadine is an antihistamine used in the management of serotonin syndrome. Serotonin syndrome can manifest with tremor, diaphoresis, nausea, agitation, anxiety, hypertension, and tachycardia, as seen in this patient. However, this patient lacks other features typical of this condition, such as fever, hyperreflexia, and myoclonus. Moreover, he has no history of ingestion of serotonergic drugs (e.g., antidepressants) that could cause serotonin syndrome.

C) CORRECT:

Benzodiazepines are the first-line therapy for alcohol withdrawal syndrome. Long-acting benzodiazepines with active metabolites (e.g., diazepam or chlordiazepoxide) are preferred because they result in a smoother withdrawal course. However, in a patient with advanced liver disease or acute alcoholic hepatitis, short- and intermediate-acting benzodiazepines with minimal first-pass metabolism and no active metabolites, such as lorazepam and oxazepam, should be used. Delirium tremens has a 5% mortality rate and must be treated urgently.

D) INCORRECT:

Dantrolene is a muscle relaxant that inhibits Ca2+ release within myocytes. It is used as a first-line therapy for malignant hyperthermia and can also be administered in cases of suspected neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS). Although malignant hyperthermia can also cause tachycardia, it usually manifests with severe hyperthermia and muscle rigidity, neither of which are seen in this patient. NMS is also characterized by muscle rigidity and hyperthermia and usually occurs after initiation of antipsychotic therapy; this patient has no history of antipsychotic use.

E) INCORRECT:

Antipsychotics, such as haloperidol, should not be used routinely in the treatment of alcohol withdrawal syndrome because they increase the risk for withdrawal seizures by lowering the seizure threshold. Moreover, these drugs may interfere with heat dissipation. Treatment with antipsychotics may be considered in case of a concomitant decompensated thought disorder (e.g., schizophrenia) after withdrawal symptoms have been successfully treated.
